line.text: Welcome to the Exclusion zone . . .
You have just arrived in Ukraine, to explore the former soviet city of Pripyat
The city of Pripyat was the ninth nuclear city in the Soviet Union founded on February 4, 1970
Once 49,400 thousand individuals lived in Pripyat
That was before . . .
April 26th, 1986: Chernobyl Nuclear power plant reactor number four suffered a catastrophic failure
The resultant release of radiation forces all residents of Pripyat to evacuate taking with them only what they could carry
The entire city is evacuated in just 3.5 hours on the afternoon of April 27th, 1986
No one is allowed back in . . .
The Exclusion zone is born.
Explore the Exclusion zone yourself and learn from the echoes of the past
Enter Pripyat from the . . .
You enter the city of Pripyat from the west
You find yourself at the intersection of pr. Stroiteley and Lesi Ukrainky St
You are 2.84 mi (4.58 km) from Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant
You are facing South East looking down Lesi Ukrainky St.
You have entered the city from the forest
Along the way you have experienced the eerie calm of the mutated forest
To your left you see a large complex of Soviet Housing
To your right you see the Jupiter factory
You have a decision to make . . .
You enter the city of Pripyat from the east
You find yourself at the intersection of Pr. Stroiteley and Ul. Geroyev Stalingrada
You are 2.69 mi (4.33 km) from Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant
You are facing South East looking down Ul. Geroyev stalingrada
You have entered the city from the river.
Along the way you have already passed many derelict soviet buildings
To the front of you, you see the Pripyat Shopping Center
To your right you see a large complex of soviet housing
You have a decision to make . . .
You find yourself in the middle of a courtyard.
You are 2.61 mi (4.2 km) from the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant.
You are facing South East
All around you are Apartment buildings.
Their occupants are missing.
Personal effects still lie exactly where they were left decades ago.
A table set for lunch.
A teddy bear staring into the abyss.
The Buildings are waiting . . .
Waiting for their occupants to return.
They never will . . .
Although people can now once again visit the City.
They cannot stay for more than a few hours.
Pripyat can be a home to none . . .
Nature is slowly reclaiming the area.
Overgrowth is found everywhere.
The city refuses to go quietly.
Built to last by the Soviet Industrial Machine.
Soviet Architects designed for efficiency and longevity.
Concrete monoliths . . .
Symbols of conformity
Relics of the past that will persist well into the future.
To your left you see a shopping center
To your right you see the Jupiter Factory
You have a decision to make . . .
You find yourself in the remains of Jupiter Factory
You are 2.62 mi (4.22 km) from the Chernobyl Nuclear Plant
Jupiter Factory is the only other major arm of the Soviet Industrial complex to be found at Pripyat
Officially, the Jupiter factory manufactured electrical components for use in tape recorders Prior to the accident.
Unofficially, the factory manufactured electronics for military use in aircraft, submarines, and perhaps even for space.
Unlike most of Pripyat however, Jupiter Factory did not die on April 26th, 1986 . . .
Following the accident the factory was repurposed to serve as a testing laboratory for decontamination.
These “unofficial” laboratories functioned up until 1996, 10 years after the disaster . . .
Following 1996 however, Jupiter factory finally met the same fate as the rest of the city.
Visiting the factory today, you see a strange mix of artifacts from 1986 and those from 1996.
To your left you see a residential complex
To your front, you see a junkyard
You have a decision to make . . .
